newsitem.title: UK: Fear creeps in as UK markets mull Labour landslide.
newsitem.headline: Fear creeps in as UK markets mull Labour landslide.

text.p: Initial market relief at an apparent landslide election victory for Britain's Labour Party rapidly gave way to fears of an over-powerful and under-experienced government.
"A reasonable Labour majority was largely what was in the market -- a very strong majority gives them the upper hand to do whatever they want," said Peter Osler, head of research at GNI.
Sterling and gilts rallied after exit polls indicated Labour -- out of government since 1979 -- was on course for a resounding victory over the ruling Conservatives.

The market's immediate reaction was to cheer the prospect of a clear victor as it dispelled fears of a slim, unworkable majority or -- the worst-case scenario for markets -- a hung parliament, where no party has a majority.
But the currency and bonds backtracked as results filtered through and traders rethought the implications of Labour domination of Britain's 659-seat parliament.

"A Labour victory has been discounted by the market but it may get a little bit concerned about the extent of the majority if it's well over 100 seats," said Corey Miller, UK equity strategist at Credit Lyonnais Laing.

"The implication being that Labour may be over-confident and resort to old' Labour, pursuing much more radical spending policies." Labour finance spokesman Gordon Brown moved fast to soothe those concerns as poll results set him on course to become Britain's next Chancellor of the Exchequer.
"We fully intend to keep all our promises and will move very quickly on a budget," Brown told ITN television news.
He said a Labour government would deliver the first budget within two months and stick to the commitments made during the election campaign.

Sterling spiked up to $1.6280 and 2.8010 marks after the first exit poll gave Labour 47 percent of the vote, with the Conservatives on just 29 percent. It stood at $1.6253/60 and 2.7970/80 marks just before the polls appeared.
But the pound had retreated to $1.6225/35 and 2.7965/75 by 2340 GMT.
Gilts gained ground initially, then fell. The benchmark 10-year 7.25 percent gilt was trading around 98-25, down from 98-27 before the exit polls and 99-07 after them.
"Because it's such a large majority it means Labour can do what they like, But what does that mean? No-one really knows," one currency trader at a European bank in Singapore said.
Sterling should be underpinned, however, by the prospects of an early interest rate rise, he added.
Analysts said a Labour government, keen to establish credibility with the markets, would probably tighten the screws quickly on monetary policy.
Bank of England governor Eddie George has long been calling for an interest rate rise -- though his advice has fallen on deaf Conservative ears.
"On the one hand this is a very strong government and a very decisive result -- but on the other hand it's something completely new," said GNI's Osler.
